kinematics.title: A.1 Kinematics
kinematics.content:
Kinematics

Kinematics is the study of motion without considering the forces that cause it. We describe motion using quantities like displacement, velocity, and acceleration.

Scalars and Vectors

Physical quantities can be classified as scalars (magnitude only) or vectors (magnitude and direction).

Examples

Scalars: distance, speed, time, mass, energy

Vectors: displacement, velocity, acceleration, force

Position, Displacement and Distance

The position of an object tells us where it is located in space. Displacement is the change in position—a vector from initial to final position. Distance is the total path length traveled (scalar).

$$\vec{\Delta x} = \vec{x}_f - \vec{x}_i$$

Velocity and Speed

Velocity is the rate of change of displacement (vector). Speed is the rate of change of distance (scalar).

$$\vec{v} = \frac{d\vec{x}}{dt}$$

Average velocity:

$$\vec{v}_{avg} = \frac{\Delta \vec{x}}{\Delta t}$$

Instantaneous velocity is the velocity at a specific moment in time—the limit of average velocity as Δt approaches zero.

Acceleration

Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity:

$$\vec{a} = \frac{d\vec{v}}{dt} = \frac{d^2\vec{x}}{dt^2}$$

Equations of Motion (SUVAT)

For uniformly accelerated motion (constant acceleration), we use the kinematic equations:

$$s = \frac{u + v}{2} \cdot t$$ $$v = u + at$$ $$s = ut + \frac{1}{2}at^2$$ $$v^2 = u^2 + 2as$$

Where: s = displacement, u = initial velocity, v = final velocity, a = acceleration, t = time

Projectile Motion

A projectile is an object moving under the influence of gravity only. Key principles:

  • Horizontal and vertical motions are independent
  • Horizontal velocity remains constant (no air resistance)
  • Vertical acceleration = g = 9.8 m/s² downward
Effect of Air Resistance

Fluid resistance reduces range, maximum height, and time of flight. The trajectory becomes asymmetric, and the object reaches terminal speed.

questions.question: Can an object have zero velocity but non-zero acceleration? Explain with an example.
questions.hint: Think about what happens at the highest point of a ball thrown upward.

questions.question: Why is displacement a vector but distance is a scalar?
questions.hint: Consider walking in a circle back to your starting point.

questions.question: A car travels 100 km east, then 60 km west. What is its distance traveled? What is its displacement?
questions.hint: Distance adds, displacement considers direction.

questions.question: In projectile motion, why does the horizontal velocity remain constant while vertical velocity changes?
questions.hint: Think about which direction gravity acts.

forces-momentum.title: A.2 Forces and Momentum
forces-momentum.content:
Forces and Momentum

Forces are interactions between bodies. They can be represented in free-body diagrams showing all forces acting on an object.

Types of Forces

Contact Forces

  • Normal force (FN): Perpendicular to surface, counteracts weight
  • Friction: Static friction: Ff ≤ μsFN; Dynamic friction: Ff = μdFN
  • Tension: Force transmitted through a rope, string, or cable
  • Elastic force: FH = −kx (Hooke's Law)
  • Viscous drag: Fd = 6πηrv (Stokes' Law for spheres)
  • Buoyancy: Fb = ρVg

Field Forces

  • Gravitational force: Fg = mg
  • Electric force: Fe
  • Magnetic force: Fm

Newton's Laws of Motion

First Law (Inertia)

An object remains at rest or in uniform motion unless acted upon by a net external force.

Second Law

The acceleration of an object is proportional to the net force and inversely proportional to mass.

$$\vec{F}_{net} = m\vec{a}$$

For changing mass systems:

$$\vec{F} = \frac{d\vec{p}}{dt}$$
Third Law (Action-Reaction)

For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction: FAB = −FBA

Momentum and Impulse

Linear momentum is defined as:

$$\vec{p} = m\vec{v}$$

Impulse is the change in momentum:

$$\vec{J} = \vec{F}\Delta t = \Delta\vec{p}$$
Conservation of Momentum

In an isolated system (no external forces), total momentum remains constant.

Collisions

  • Elastic collision: Both momentum and kinetic energy conserved
  • Inelastic collision: Only momentum conserved; KE is lost
  • Perfectly inelastic: Objects stick together; maximum KE loss

Circular Motion

Objects moving in circles experience centripetal acceleration directed toward the center:

$$a = \frac{v^2}{r} = \omega^2 r = \frac{4\pi^2 r}{T^2}$$

Angular velocity relates to linear speed:

$$v = \frac{2\pi r}{T} = \omega r$$

questions.question: If action and reaction forces are equal and opposite, why don't they cancel out?
questions.hint: Consider which object each force acts upon.

questions.question: Why does a heavy truck cause more damage in a collision than a small car traveling at the same speed?
questions.hint: Think about momentum and impulse.

questions.question: Why is it easier to push a box that's already moving than to start it moving?
questions.hint: Compare static and dynamic friction coefficients.

questions.question: In circular motion, what provides the centripetal force for a car going around a curve?
questions.hint: Think about what force acts between the tires and road.

work-energy-power.title: A.3 Work, Energy and Power
work-energy-power.content:
Work, Energy and Power

Energy is one of the most fundamental concepts in physics—the capacity to do work or produce change.

Work

Work is done when a force causes displacement:

$$W = Fs\cos\theta$$

where θ is the angle between force and displacement. Work equals the area under a force-displacement graph.

Key Insight

Work done by the resultant force equals the change in kinetic energy of the object.

Forms of Mechanical Energy

Kinetic Energy

$$E_K = \frac{1}{2}mv^2 = \frac{p^2}{2m}$$

Gravitational Potential Energy

(Near Earth's surface)

$$E_P = mgh$$

Elastic Potential Energy

$$E_H = \frac{1}{2}kx^2$$

Conservation of Energy

Fundamental Principle

Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed. In the absence of friction, total mechanical energy is conserved.

Energy transfers can be represented using Sankey diagrams showing input, useful output, and wasted energy.

Power

Power is the rate of doing work or transferring energy:

$$P = \frac{W}{t} = Fv$$

Efficiency

$$\eta = \frac{E_{output}}{E_{input}} = \frac{P_{output}}{P_{input}}$$

Energy Density

The energy density of a fuel is the energy released per unit mass or volume of fuel.

questions.question: If you push hard against a wall but it doesn't move, have you done any work on the wall? Explain.
questions.hint: Work requires both force AND displacement.

questions.question: Why does a pendulum eventually stop swinging even though energy is conserved?
questions.hint: Is the pendulum system truly isolated?

questions.question: A ball is thrown upward. At what point is its kinetic energy maximum? Minimum? What about potential energy?
questions.hint: Think about where velocity is greatest/smallest.

questions.question: Two cars have the same kinetic energy. One has twice the mass of the other. Which is moving faster and by what factor?
questions.hint: Use the kinetic energy equation to find the relationship.

rigid-body-mechanics.title: A.4 Rigid Body Mechanics
rigid-body-mechanics.content:
Rigid Body Mechanics

This is Higher Level content.

Rotational Motion

Extended bodies can rotate about an axis. We describe rotation using angular displacement (θ), angular velocity (ω), and angular acceleration (α).

Equations of Angular Motion

For uniform angular acceleration:

$$\theta = \frac{\omega_f + \omega_i}{2}t$$ $$\omega_f = \omega_i + \alpha t$$ $$\theta = \omega_i t + \frac{1}{2}\alpha t^2$$ $$\omega_f^2 = \omega_i^2 + 2\alpha\theta$$

Moment of Inertia

The moment of inertia depends on mass distribution about the rotation axis:

$$I = \sum mr^2$$

Torque

Torque is the rotational equivalent of force:

$$\tau = Fr\sin\theta$$

Newton's second law for rotation:

$$\tau = I\alpha$$

Angular Momentum

$$L = I\omega$$
Conservation of Angular Momentum

Angular momentum remains constant unless acted upon by a resultant torque.

Angular impulse: ΔL = τΔt

Rotational Kinetic Energy

$$E_K = \frac{1}{2}I\omega^2 = \frac{L^2}{2I}$$

questions.question: Why does an ice skater spin faster when they pull their arms in?
questions.hint: Think about angular momentum conservation and moment of inertia.

questions.question: Why is it harder to stop a spinning merry-go-round with children at the edge versus the center?
questions.hint: Consider how mass distribution affects moment of inertia.

galilean-relativity.title: A.5 Galilean & Special Relativity
galilean-relativity.content:
Galilean & Special Relativity

This is Higher Level content.

Reference Frames

A reference frame is a coordinate system used to describe motion. An inertial reference frame is one where Newton's laws hold.

Galilean Relativity

In classical mechanics, transformations between frames:

$$x' = x - vt$$ $$t' = t$$ $$u' = u - v$$

Einstein's Postulates

The Two Postulates

1. The laws of physics are the same in all inertial reference frames.

2. The speed of light in a vacuum (c) is constant for all observers.

Lorentz Transformations

$$x' = \gamma(x - vt)$$ $$t' = \gamma\left(t - \frac{vx}{c^2}\right)$$

where the Lorentz factor is:

$$\gamma = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - \frac{v^2}{c^2}}}$$

Time Dilation

Moving clocks run slower:

$$\Delta t = \gamma\Delta t_0$$

Length Contraction

Moving objects are shorter in the direction of motion:

$$L = \frac{L_0}{\gamma}$$

Evidence

Muon decay experiments provide evidence for time dilation and length contraction.

questions.question: Why can nothing travel faster than light according to special relativity?
questions.hint: Consider what happens to γ as v approaches c.

questions.question: If you're on a spaceship traveling at 0.9c, why don't you feel like time is passing slowly?
questions.hint: Think about which observer measures proper time.

thermal-energy-transfers.title: B.1 Thermal Energy Transfers
thermal-energy-transfers.content:
Thermal Energy Transfers

Molecular Theory

Matter consists of particles in constant random motion. The state (solid, liquid, gas) depends on the balance between kinetic energy and intermolecular forces.

Density

$$\rho = \frac{m}{V}$$

Temperature Scales

Temperature can be expressed in Kelvin (K) or Celsius (°C). A change of 1 K equals a change of 1°C.

Kelvin temperature relates to average kinetic energy of particles:

$$\bar{E}_K = \frac{3}{2}k_B T$$

Internal Energy

Internal energy is the sum of all molecular kinetic energies plus intermolecular potential energies.

Specific Heat Capacity

$$Q = mc\Delta T$$

Specific Latent Heat

Energy for phase changes at constant temperature:

$$Q = mL$$

Heat Transfer Mechanisms

  • Conduction: Energy transfer through particle collisions
  • Convection: Energy transfer by fluid movement due to density differences
  • Radiation: Energy transfer by electromagnetic waves

Rate of conduction:

$$\frac{Q}{t} = kA\frac{\Delta T}{\Delta x}$$

Black Body Radiation

Stefan-Boltzmann Law:

$$L = \sigma AT^4$$

Wien's Displacement Law:

$$\lambda_{max}T = 2.9 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m·K}$$

questions.question: Why does a metal spoon feel colder than a wooden spoon at the same temperature?
questions.hint: Think about thermal conductivity and heat transfer to your hand.

questions.question: Why does water stay at 100°C while boiling even though you keep adding heat?
questions.hint: Where does the energy go during a phase change?

questions.question: Why do hot air balloons rise?
questions.hint: Think about how temperature affects density.

greenhouse-effect.title: B.2 Greenhouse Effect
greenhouse-effect.content:
The Greenhouse Effect

Emissivity and Albedo

Emissivity is the ratio of power radiated compared to a black body at the same temperature.

Albedo measures average reflected energy:

$$\text{Albedo} = \frac{\text{Total scattered power}}{\text{Total incident power}}$$

Solar Constant

The solar constant S ≈ 1361 W/m² is the intensity of solar radiation at Earth's distance.

Average intensity received:

$$\bar{I} = \frac{S}{4}$$

Greenhouse Gases

Main greenhouse gases: CO₂, H₂O, CH₄, N₂O

These absorb infrared radiation due to molecular vibrations matching IR frequencies. They re-emit in all directions, trapping heat.

Enhanced Greenhouse Effect

Human activities increase greenhouse gas concentrations, enhancing the natural greenhouse effect and causing global warming.

questions.question: Why does the Earth's temperature remain relatively stable despite constant solar input?
questions.hint: Think about energy balance between incoming and outgoing radiation.

questions.question: Why can N₂ and O₂ (the main atmospheric gases) not act as greenhouse gases?
questions.hint: Consider molecular structure and vibration modes.

gas-laws.title: B.3 Gas Laws
gas-laws.content:
Gas Laws

Pressure

$$P = \frac{F}{A}$$

Amount of Substance

$$n = \frac{N}{N_A}$$

where NA = 6.02 × 10²³ mol⁻¹ (Avogadro's constant)

Ideal Gas Model

An ideal gas consists of point particles with no intermolecular forces except during elastic collisions. Real gases approximate this at low pressure and high temperature.

Ideal Gas Law

$$PV = nRT = Nk_BT$$

Kinetic Theory

Pressure arises from molecular collisions:

$$P = \frac{1}{3}\rho\bar{v}^2$$

Internal Energy of Ideal Gas

$$U = \frac{3}{2}Nk_BT = \frac{3}{2}nRT$$

questions.question: Why does a balloon expand when heated?
questions.hint: Use the ideal gas law to think about what happens when T increases at constant P.

questions.question: Why do real gases deviate from ideal behavior at high pressures?
questions.hint: Think about the assumptions of the ideal gas model.

thermodynamics.title: B.4 Thermodynamics
thermodynamics.content:
Thermodynamics

This is Higher Level content.

First Law of Thermodynamics

$$Q = \Delta U + W$$

Heat added = Change in internal energy + Work done by system

Thermodynamic Processes

  • Isothermal: Constant temperature (ΔU = 0)
  • Isobaric: Constant pressure
  • Isovolumetric: Constant volume (W = 0)
  • Adiabatic: No heat transfer (Q = 0)

For adiabatic processes in monatomic gases:

$$PV^{5/3} = \text{constant}$$

Entropy

Entropy measures disorder:

$$\Delta S = \frac{Q}{T}$$ $$S = k_B \ln\Omega$$

Second Law of Thermodynamics

The Law

The entropy of an isolated system never decreases. Real processes are irreversible.

Heat Engines

Efficiency:

$$\eta = \frac{\text{Useful work}}{\text{Input energy}}$$

Carnot efficiency (maximum possible):

$$\eta_{Carnot} = 1 - \frac{T_c}{T_h}$$

questions.question: Why can no heat engine be 100% efficient?
questions.hint: Consider the second law and entropy.

questions.question: Why does compressing a gas cause it to heat up?
questions.hint: Think about the first law and adiabatic compression.

current-circuits.title: B.5 Current and Circuits
current-circuits.content:
Current and Circuits

Electric Current

Electric current is the flow of charge carriers:

$$I = \frac{\Delta q}{\Delta t}$$

Potential Difference

Work done per unit charge:

$$V = \frac{W}{q}$$

Resistance and Resistivity

$$R = \frac{V}{I}$$ $$\rho = \frac{RA}{L}$$

Ohm's Law

For ohmic conductors, R is constant (V ∝ I). Non-ohmic conductors (like diodes, filament bulbs) have varying resistance.

Series and Parallel Circuits

Series

  • Current: I = I₁ = I₂ = ...
  • Voltage: V = V₁ + V₂ + ...
  • Resistance: Rs = R₁ + R₂ + ...

Parallel

  • Current: I = I₁ + I₂ + ...
  • Voltage: V = V₁ = V₂ = ...
  • Resistance: 1/Rp = 1/R₁ + 1/R₂ + ...

Power

$$P = IV = I^2R = \frac{V^2}{R}$$

EMF and Internal Resistance

$$\varepsilon = I(R + r)$$

questions.question: Why does a lightbulb in series with a battery get dimmer when you add more bulbs in series?
questions.hint: Think about how total resistance affects current.

questions.question: A wire is stretched to twice its length. What happens to its resistance?
questions.hint: Consider how both length and cross-sectional area change.

simple-harmonic-motion.title: C.1 Simple Harmonic Motion
simple-harmonic-motion.content:
Simple Harmonic Motion

Definition

SHM occurs when acceleration is proportional to displacement and directed toward equilibrium:

$$a = -\omega^2 x$$

Key Relationships

$$T = \frac{1}{f} = \frac{2\pi}{\omega}$$

Simple Pendulum

$$T = 2\pi\sqrt{\frac{l}{g}}$$

Mass-Spring System

$$T = 2\pi\sqrt{\frac{m}{k}}$$

Equations of Motion (HL)

This is Higher Level content.

$$x = x_0\sin(\omega t + \phi)$$ $$v = x_0\omega\cos(\omega t + \phi)$$ $$v = \pm\omega\sqrt{x_0^2 - x^2}$$

Energy in SHM

$$E_T = \frac{1}{2}m\omega^2 x_0^2$$ $$E_P = \frac{1}{2}m\omega^2 x^2$$

questions.question: At what point in its oscillation does a pendulum have maximum velocity? Maximum acceleration?
questions.hint: Think about where velocity is changing most rapidly.

questions.question: If you double the mass on a spring, what happens to the period?
questions.hint: Use the equation for period of a mass-spring system.

wave-model.title: C.2 Wave Model
wave-model.content:
Wave Model

Wave Types

  • Transverse waves: Oscillation perpendicular to direction of travel (e.g., light, waves on a string)
  • Longitudinal waves: Oscillation parallel to direction of travel (e.g., sound)

Wave Properties

$$v = f\lambda = \frac{\lambda}{T}$$

Sound Waves

Sound is a longitudinal mechanical wave requiring a medium. Speed depends on the medium's properties.

Electromagnetic Waves

EM waves are transverse waves that can travel through vacuum at c = 3 × 10⁸ m/s. The spectrum ranges from radio waves to gamma rays.

questions.question: Why can't sound travel through space?
questions.hint: Think about what sound waves need to propagate.

questions.question: If you double the frequency of a wave, what happens to its wavelength?
questions.hint: Use the wave equation v = fλ, assuming v is constant.

wave-phenomenon.title: C.3 Wave Phenomena
wave-phenomenon.content:
Wave Phenomena

Wavefronts and Rays

Wavefronts are lines of constant phase. Rays show direction of energy propagation.

Reflection and Refraction

Snell's Law:

$$\frac{n_1}{n_2} = \frac{\sin\theta_2}{\sin\theta_1} = \frac{v_2}{v_1}$$

Total Internal Reflection

Occurs when light travels from denser to less dense medium at angles greater than the critical angle.

Diffraction

Waves spread out when passing through apertures or around obstacles. Most significant when aperture ≈ wavelength.

Superposition

When waves overlap, displacements add. This leads to interference:

  • Constructive: Path difference = nλ
  • Destructive: Path difference = (n + ½)λ

Young's Double Slit

$$s = \frac{\lambda D}{d}$$

where s = fringe separation, D = distance to screen, d = slit separation

Diffraction Gratings (HL)

This is Higher Level content.

$$n\lambda = d\sin\theta$$

questions.question: Why can you hear someone around a corner but not see them?
questions.hint: Compare the wavelengths of sound and light to typical obstacles.

questions.question: Why does a thin film of oil on water show rainbow colors?
questions.hint: Think about interference of reflected light.

standing-waves-resonance.title: C.4 Standing Waves and Resonance
standing-waves-resonance.content:
Standing Waves and Resonance

Formation

Standing waves form from superposition of two identical waves traveling in opposite directions.

Nodes and Antinodes

  • Nodes: Points of zero amplitude (destructive interference)
  • Antinodes: Points of maximum amplitude (constructive interference)

Strings and Pipes

Standing wave patterns depend on boundary conditions:

  • Fixed ends create nodes
  • Open ends create antinodes

Resonance

Resonance occurs when a system is driven at its natural frequency, producing maximum amplitude response.

Damping

  • Light damping: Slow decay, sharp resonance peak
  • Critical damping: Fastest return to equilibrium without oscillation
  • Heavy damping: Very slow return, no oscillation

questions.question: Why do some musical instruments produce different notes for the same-length air column?
questions.hint: Think about open vs closed pipes and their harmonics.

questions.question: Why might soldiers break step when crossing a bridge?
questions.hint: Consider what happens if marching frequency matches the bridge's natural frequency.

doppler-effect.title: C.5 Doppler Effect
doppler-effect.content:
Doppler Effect

The Effect

The Doppler effect is the change in observed frequency when source and observer are in relative motion.

Light (Low Speeds)

$$\frac{\Delta f}{f} = \frac{\Delta \lambda}{\lambda} \approx \frac{v}{c}$$
  • Redshift: Source moving away (wavelength increases)
  • Blueshift: Source approaching (wavelength decreases)

Spectral line shifts reveal stellar and galactic motion.

Sound (HL)

This is Higher Level content.

Moving source:

$$f' = f\frac{v}{v \mp u_s}$$

Moving observer:

$$f' = f\frac{v \pm u_o}{v}$$

questions.question: Why does a fire truck's siren sound higher-pitched as it approaches you?
questions.hint: Think about how the motion affects the wavelength reaching you.

questions.question: How do astronomers use redshift to determine if a galaxy is moving toward or away from us?
questions.hint: Consider whether wavelengths get stretched or compressed.

gravitational-fields.title: D.1 Gravitational Fields
gravitational-fields.content:
Gravitational Fields

Kepler's Laws

  1. Planets orbit in ellipses with the Sun at one focus
  2. A line from planet to Sun sweeps equal areas in equal times
  3. T² ∝ r³ for all planets

Newton's Law of Gravitation

$$F = \frac{Gm_1m_2}{r^2}$$

Gravitational Field Strength

$$g = \frac{F}{m} = \frac{GM}{r^2}$$

Gravitational Potential (HL)

This is Higher Level content.

$$V_g = -\frac{GM}{r}$$

Gravitational Potential Energy (HL)

$$E_p = -\frac{GMm}{r}$$

Orbital and Escape Speed (HL)

$$v_{orbital} = \sqrt{\frac{GM}{r}}$$ $$v_{escape} = \sqrt{\frac{2GM}{r}}$$

questions.question: Why do astronauts feel weightless in orbit even though gravity is still acting on them?
questions.hint: Think about what the astronaut and spacecraft are both doing.

questions.question: Why is gravitational potential energy negative?
questions.hint: Consider what the zero point of potential energy is defined as.

electric-magnetic-fields.title: D.2 Electric and Magnetic Fields
electric-magnetic-fields.content:
Electric and Magnetic Fields

Electric Charge

Charge is conserved and quantized. Like charges repel; opposite charges attract.

Coulomb's Law

$$F = k\frac{q_1q_2}{r^2}$$

where k = 8.99 × 10⁹ N·m²/C²

Electric Field Strength

$$E = \frac{F}{q}$$

Uniform Field (Parallel Plates)

$$E = \frac{V}{d}$$

Electric Potential (HL)

This is Higher Level content.

$$V_e = \frac{kQ}{r}$$ $$E_p = \frac{kq_1q_2}{r}$$

Magnetic Field Lines

Magnetic fields are represented by field lines. For a bar magnet, lines exit north and enter south poles.

questions.question: Why does a charged balloon stick to a neutral wall?
questions.hint: Think about induced charges in the wall.

questions.question: How is the electric field between parallel plates different from around a point charge?
questions.hint: Consider field line patterns and uniformity.

motion-em-fields.title: D.3 Motion in EM Fields
motion-em-fields.content:
Motion in Electromagnetic Fields

Charged Particle in Electric Field

A charged particle accelerates in the direction of the field (positive) or opposite (negative).

Change in kinetic energy = qV

Charged Particle in Magnetic Field

The magnetic force is perpendicular to both velocity and field, causing circular motion:

$$F = qvB\sin\theta$$

Radius of circular path:

$$r = \frac{mv}{qB}$$

Force on Current-Carrying Wire

$$F = BIL\sin\theta$$

Force Between Parallel Wires

$$\frac{F}{L} = \frac{\mu_0 I_1 I_2}{2\pi r}$$

questions.question: Why does a charged particle in a uniform magnetic field move in a circle rather than a straight line?
questions.hint: Think about the direction of the magnetic force relative to velocity.

questions.question: Two parallel wires carry current in the same direction. Do they attract or repel?
questions.hint: Consider the magnetic field each wire creates at the other's location.

induction.title: D.4 Induction
induction.content:
Electromagnetic Induction

Magnetic Flux

$$\Phi = BA\cos\theta$$

Faraday's Law

A changing magnetic flux induces an EMF:

$$\varepsilon = -N\frac{\Delta\Phi}{\Delta t}$$

EMF in Moving Conductor

$$\varepsilon = BvL$$

Lenz's Law

The Law

The induced current flows in a direction that opposes the change causing it. This is a consequence of energy conservation.

AC Generators

A rotating coil in a magnetic field produces sinusoidal EMF. Increasing rotation frequency increases both EMF amplitude and frequency.

questions.question: Why does dropping a magnet through a copper tube take longer than through a plastic tube?
questions.hint: Think about induced currents and Lenz's law.

questions.question: Why must a generator coil be rotated to produce a continuous current?
questions.hint: Consider what happens to flux when the coil is stationary.

structure-atom.title: E.1 Structure of the Atom
structure-atom.content:
Structure of the Atom

Rutherford Scattering

The Geiger-Marsden experiment revealed the nuclear model: alpha particles were deflected by a small, dense, positive nucleus.

Nuclear Notation

$$^A_Z X$$

A = nucleon number (protons + neutrons), Z = proton number

Atomic Spectra

Emission and absorption spectra provide evidence for discrete energy levels. Photons are emitted/absorbed during transitions:

$$\Delta E = hf$$

Nuclear Radius (HL)

This is Higher Level content.

$$R = R_0 A^{1/3}$$

Bohr Model for Hydrogen (HL)

$$E_n = \frac{-13.6}{n^2} \text{ eV}$$

Angular momentum is quantized:

$$mvr = \frac{nh}{2\pi}$$

questions.question: Why did Rutherford's experiment disprove the 'plum pudding' model?
questions.hint: Consider what would happen to alpha particles if positive charge were spread out.

questions.question: Why do different elements have different emission spectra?
questions.hint: Think about energy level differences being unique to each element.

quantum-physics.title: E.2 Quantum Physics
quantum-physics.content:
Quantum Physics

This is Higher Level content.

Photoelectric Effect

Light ejects electrons from metals only if frequency exceeds threshold f₀:

$$E_{max} = hf - \phi$$

where φ is the work function.

Compton Scattering

Photons scatter off electrons with increased wavelength:

$$\Delta\lambda = \frac{h}{m_e c}(1 - \cos\theta)$$

Wave-Particle Duality

Matter exhibits both wave and particle properties. The de Broglie wavelength:

$$\lambda = \frac{h}{p}$$

Electron diffraction provides evidence for matter waves.

questions.question: Why doesn't increasing the intensity of light below threshold frequency cause electron emission?
questions.hint: Think about what intensity and frequency each represent for photons.

questions.question: Why don't we observe wave-like behavior for everyday objects?
questions.hint: Calculate the de Broglie wavelength for a macroscopic object.

radioactive-decay.title: E.3 Radioactive Decay
radioactive-decay.content:
Radioactive Decay

Isotopes

Isotopes are atoms with same proton number but different neutron numbers. Some are unstable and decay radioactively.

Types of Radiation

  • Alpha (α): ²₄He nucleus - high ionizing, low penetrating
  • Beta⁻ (β⁻): electron + antineutrino - medium ionizing/penetrating
  • Beta⁺ (β⁺): positron + neutrino
  • Gamma (γ): high-energy photon - low ionizing, high penetrating

Decay Equations

Nuclear notation shows conservation of nucleon and proton numbers.

Half-Life

The half-life is the time for half of a radioactive sample to decay. Decay is random and spontaneous.

Binding Energy

The mass defect is converted to binding energy:

$$E = mc^2$$

Decay Law (HL)

This is Higher Level content.

$$N = N_0 e^{-\lambda t}$$ $$A = \lambda N$$ $$T_{1/2} = \frac{\ln 2}{\lambda}$$

questions.question: Why can we never predict exactly when a particular nucleus will decay?
questions.hint: Think about the probability nature of radioactive decay.

questions.question: Why is alpha radiation dangerous if inhaled but not through skin, while gamma is dangerous externally?
questions.hint: Consider ionizing power and penetration ability.

fission.title: E.4 Fission
fission.content:
Nuclear Fission

The Process

Nuclear fission is the splitting of a heavy nucleus into lighter fragments, releasing energy.

Chain Reactions

Neutrons released can trigger further fissions. For sustained reactions, at least one neutron per fission must cause another fission (criticality).

Nuclear Reactors

  • Moderator: Slows neutrons (e.g., water, graphite)
  • Control rods: Absorb neutrons to control reaction rate
  • Heat exchanger: Transfers thermal energy to generate steam
  • Shielding: Contains radiation

Management of Products

Fission products are highly radioactive and require long-term storage solutions.

fusion-stars.title: E.5 Fusion and Stars
fusion-stars.content:
Fusion and Stars

Nuclear Fusion

Fusion is combining light nuclei to form heavier ones, releasing energy. Requires extreme temperature and pressure.

Stellar Stability

Stars are stable when radiation pressure outward balances gravitational force inward.

The HR Diagram

The Hertzsprung-Russell diagram plots luminosity vs temperature:

  • Main sequence: Hydrogen-burning stars
  • Red giants: Evolved stars, helium burning
  • White dwarfs: Remnants of low-mass stars

Stellar Evolution

A star's fate depends on its mass: low-mass → white dwarf; high-mass → supernova → neutron star or black hole.

Measuring Distance

Stellar parallax:

$$d(\text{parsec}) = \frac{1}{p(\text{arc-second})}$$

questions.question: Why can't fusion reactors on Earth simply copy what happens in stars?
questions.hint: Think about what contains the plasma in a star vs on Earth.
